facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1950 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1950. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 29th June 1950 of High Court of Judicature at Simla by Weston J. and Khosla J. in Criminal Appeal No. 432 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated 29th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Simla  Weston J. and Khosla J.  in Criminal Appeal No. 432 of 1949

facts.text: High Court appeal arose out of judgment dated 5th August 1949 of Additional Sessions Judge Amritsar in Sessions Trial No. 7 of 1949 and Case No. 8 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of a judgment dated 5th August, 1949, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Amritsar, in Ses- sions Trial No. 7 of 1949 and Case No. 8 of 1949.

facts.text: Three appellants tried by Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of murdering Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh, sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab upheld conviction and sentence of appellants and granted certificate under article 134(1)(c) of Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence and granted them a certificate under article 134 1  c of the Constitution that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: On evening of 16th December 1948, little before sunset, Achhar Singh went to house of Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

anchor.surface_text: On the evening of 16th December, 1948, a little before sunset, Achhar Singh, one of the murdered persons, went to the house of one Inder Singh in village Dalam for getting paddy husked.

facts.text: Darshan Singh, brother of Achhar Singh, working as driver at Amritsar, came to Dalam from Amritsar same evening and went to Inder Singh's house on learning Achhar was there.

anchor.surface_text: Achhar Singhs brother, Darshan Singh, who was working as a driver at Amritsar, came to Dalam from Amritsar the same evening, and, on learning to know from his father that Achhar Singh had gone to Inder Singhs house, he also went there.

facts.text: While two brothers Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh returning home, attacked by three appellants and two relatives in lane adjoining Inder Singh's house.

anchor.surface_text: while the two brothers were returning home, they were attacked by the three appellants and two of their relatives in a lane adjoining Inder Singhs house.

facts.text: Five assailants armed with deadly weapons inflicted number of injuries on two victims, resulting in their death then and there.

anchor.surface_text: The five assailants, who were armed with deadly weapons, in- flicted a number of injuries on the two victims, as a result of which they died then and there.

facts.text: After murder, appellants and companions tied two dead bodies in two kheses (wrappers) and took them to village Saleempura.

anchor.surface_text: After the murder, the appellants and their companions tied the two dead bodies in two kheses  wrappers  and took them to village Saleempura

facts.text: At Saleempura, Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh joined them, dead bodies dismembered and thrown into stream Sakinala about five miles from Dalam.

anchor.surface_text: where two other persons, named Ajaib Singh and Banta Singh, joined them, and the dead bodies after being dismembered were thrown into a stream known as Sakinala at a place about five miles from village Dalam.

facts.text: Bela Singh, father of deceased, claims to have witnessed occurrence, did not leave village at night due to fear, started two hours before sunrise next morning, lodged FIR at 10 A.M. at nearest police station.

anchor.surface_text: Bela Singh, father of the deceased persons, who was one of the persons who claims to have witnessed the occurrence, did not leave the village at night on account of fear, but he started about two hours before sunrise on the next morning and lodged the first information report at 10 A.M. at the nearest police station.

facts.text: Police officer arrived in village Dalam shortly after FIR.

anchor.surface_text: A police officer arrived in village Dalam shortly after- wards,

facts.text: After investigation, charge-sheet submitted against seven persons including present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: and after investigation a charge-sheet was submitted against seven persons including the present appellants.

facts.text: At trial, five accused charged under section 302/149 and 201/149 IPC, two under 201/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, five of the accused were charged with offences under section 302 read with section 149 and under section 201 read with section 149 of the Indian Penal Code. and the remaining two accused were charged with the offence under section 201 read with section 149 of that Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants and two others under 302/149 to life transportation, Ajaib Singh under 201/149 to 3 years RI, Banta Singh acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who tried the accused, convicted the appellants and two other persons under section 302 read with section 149 of the Penal Code and sentenced them to transportation for life, and convicted Ajaib Singh under section 201 read with section 149 and sentenced him to three years R.I. Bantu Singh, accused, was acquitted.

facts.text: Punjab High Court on appeal upheld conviction of present appellants, acquitted remaining three.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Punjab High Court upheld the conviction of the present appellants and acquitted the remaining three persons.

facts.text: In June 1947, Natha Singh, father of third appellant Swaran Singh, was murdered.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in June, 1947, Natha Singh, father of the third appellant, Swaran Singh, was murdered,

facts.text: Darshan Singh, Achhar Singh, and Sulakhan Singh charged with murder of Natha Singh; Darshan acquitted, Achhar 1.5 years RI, Sulakhan 7 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: and Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh, the two mur- dered persons in the case before us, and their third broth- er, Sulakhan Singh, were charged with the murder of that person. As a result of the trial, Darshan Singh was acquit- ted and Achhar Singh was sentenced to 11/2 years R.I., while Sulakhan Singh was sentenced to 7 years R.I.

facts.text: Judgment in Natha Singh murder case delivered shortly before 16 Dec 1948; Achhar Singh released on bail by appellate court and at large.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Sessions Judge in that case was delivered shortly before the date of the present occurrence, and it is common ground that Achhar Singh had been released on bail by the appellate court and was at large at that time.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants conceded facts constituted strong motive for murder.

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us by the learned counsel for the appellants that the facts stated above constituted a strong motive for the murder,

facts.text: Second appellant Massa Singh arrested on 18th December 1948 wearing pyjama stained with human blood.

anchor.surface_text: The second appellant, Massa Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, was wearing a pyjama stained with human blood.

facts.text: Third appellant Swaran Singh arrested on 18th December 1948, on 19th December took police to locked haveli, two kheses wrappers stained with human blood recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The third appellant, Swaran Singh, who was arrested on the 18th December, 1948, took the police on the 19th December to his haveli which was locked, and, on opening it two kheses  wrappers  which were stained with human blood were recovered.

facts.text: Swaran Singh pointed out spot on way to Sakinala where dead bodies placed temporarily, blood-stained earth scrapped by police.

anchor.surface_text: Swaran Singh pointed out a spot on the way to Saki- nala, where the two dead bodies were placed for a short time while they were being taken to Sakinala, and the police scrapped blood-stained earth from that spot.

facts.text: Swaran Singh led police to bank of Sakinala and pointed out trunk of body of Darshan Singh lying in nala.

anchor.surface_text: He also led the police to the bank of Sakinala and pointed out the trunk of the body of Darshan Singh which was lying in the nala.

facts.text: Lachhman Singh arrested on 28th December 1948, pointed out dilapidated khola near Sakinala where 3 spears, one kirpan and a datar stained with human blood recovered.

anchor.surface_text: Lachhman Singh, who was arrested on the 28th Decem- ber, 1948, pointed out a dilapidated khola near Sakinala where 3 spears, one kirpan and a datar, all stained with human blood, were recovered.

facts.text: Direct evidence consists of testimony of four eye-witnesses: Bela Singh, Inder Singh and wife Mst. Taro, Gurcharan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The direct evidence consists of the testimony of four eye-witnesses, namely, Bela Singh, father of the deceased, who claims to have gone to the scene of occurrence on hearing an outcry and to have witnessed the murderous assault on his sons Inder Singh and his wife, Mst. Taro, ...

facts.text: On morning of 19th December 1948, three accused Katba Singh, Massa Singh, Swaran Singh interrogated by police and made statements recorded disclosing dead bodies thrown in Sakinala.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution, all the three accused, namely, Katba Singh, Massa Singh and Swaran Singh, were interrogated by the police on the morning of the 19th Decem- ber, 1948, and they made certain statements which were duly recorded by the police. In these statements, it was disclosed that the dead bodies were thrown in the Sakinala.

facts.text: Doctor performing post-mortem found partially digested rice in stomach of two deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants pointed out that the doctor who performed the post-mortem examination of the corpses, found partially digested rice in the stomach of the two deceased persons,

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on 21 March 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. March 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZL ALl J.

issues.text: Whether, as a matter of prudence and caution, it is proper to rely on oral evidence of eye-witnesses implicating particular accused without circumstantial corroboration, and whether such corroboration exists against each appellant

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges of the High Court, though they repelled most of the criticisms levelled against the witnesses, ultimately came to the conclusion that in all the circumstances of the case it would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it.

issues.text: What is the scope of interference by the Supreme Court in a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and High Court

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this Court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

issues.text: Whether the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh are admissible under section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, particularly when multiple accused provided information about the location of dead bodies

anchor.surface_text: The comment against the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh was that they are not admissible in evidence under section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, which provides-- When any fact is deposed to as discovered in consequence of information received from a person accused of an offence in the custody of a police officer,

issues.text: Whether the recovery of blood-stained weapons at the instance of Lachhman Singh should be discarded due to suspicious police investigation

anchor.surface_text: As to the recovery of blood-stained weapons at the instance of Lachhman Singh, it was urged that the entire evidence with regard to this recovery should be discarded, as the police investigation in the case was not a straightforward one but was conducted in such a way as to raise suspicion that the police were deliberately trying to create some evidence of recovery against each of the accused persons.

issues.text: Whether the blood-stained pyjama recovered from Massa Singh provides reliable corroborative evidence

anchor.surface_text: The comment of the learned counsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from Massa Singh was, firstly, that it was not possible to gather from the evidence the extent of the blood stains, and secondly that it would be highly improbable that this accused person would be so reckless as to continue to wear a blood stained pyjama after having perpetrated the crime.

issues.text: Whether the post-mortem findings regarding partially digested rice in the stomachs of the deceased contradict the prosecution case on time of occurrence

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants pointed out that the doctor who performed the post-mortem examination of the corpses, found partially digested rice in the stomach of the two deceased persons, and he urged that from this it would be inferred that the occurrence must have taken place sometime at night after the deceased persons had taken their evening meals together.

arguments.claim: Facts of prior murder constitute equally strong motive for appellants being falsely implicated since murder committed in circumstances where murderers could not be identified

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us by the learned counsel for the appellants that the facts stated above constituted a strong motive for the murder, but he also contended that they constituted an equally strong motive for the appellants being falsely implicated in case the murder was committed, as was suggested by him, in circumstances under which the murderers could not be seen or identified.

arguments.claim: Eye-witness oral evidence implicating particular accused unreliable without circumstantial corroboration

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges of the High Court, though they repelled most of the criticisms levelled against the witnesses, ultimately came to the conclusion that in all the circumstances of the case it would be proper not to rely upon the oral evidence implicating particular accused unless there is some circumstantial evidence to support it.

arguments.claim: Direct evidence of eye-witnesses consistent, reliable, establishes guilt of five accused including appellants

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, who heard the evidence, seems to have been impressed by the evidence of the eye- witnesses, and he has summed up his conclusion in these words -- This evidence was so consistent, so reliable, and of such nature that in my opinion it is definitely established that the five accused Lachhman Singh, Katha Singh, Massa, Singh, Charan Singh and Swaran Singh are proved to have actually murdered both Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ith the case, did number companydemn the oral evidence outright, but, as a matter of prudence and caution, they decided number to companyvict an accus

arguments.court_reasoning: HC accepted reliability but required circumstantial corroboration for particular accused; SC upholds HC approach

arguments.claim: Circumstantial evidence sufficient corroboration of oral evidence against each of the three appellants

anchor.surface_text: Having laid down this standard, they examined the circum- stantial evidence against each of the accused persons and upheld the conviction of the three appellants on the ground that the circumstantial evidence, to which reference has been made, was sufficient corroboration of the oral evi- dence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: for their own guidance. The companyment of the learned companynsel for the appellants with regard to the blood-stained pyjama which was recovered from

arguments.court_reasoning: SC finds case of each appellant falls within the rule; corroboration lends assurance

arguments.claim: Supreme Court interference in criminal appeal limited after sifting by trial court and High Court; will not reassess evidence or rejected fact points

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding, however, upon the principles laid down by this Court, circumscribing the scope of a criminal appeal after the case has been sifted by the trial court and the High Court, it seems to us that the question involved in the present appeal is a short and simple one.

arguments.claim: Corroboration required for eye-witness evidence is not accomplice-level but circumstances lending assurance that particular accused concerned in murder

anchor.surface_text: According to our reading of the judgment of the High Court, the learned Judges, who dealt with the case, did not condemn the oral evidence outright, but, as a matter of prudence and caution, they decided not to convict an accused person unless there were some circumstances to lend support to the evidence of the eye-witnesses with regard to him.

arguments.claim: Recoveries under S.27 admissible even from multiple accused if independent statements lead to distinct discoveries; prior cases limiting to first may be reviewed

anchor.surface_text: But as to what should be the rule when there is clear and unimpeachable evidence as to independent and authentic statements of the nature referred to in section 27 of the Evidence Act, having been made by several accused persons, either simultaneously or otherwise, all that we wish to say is that as at present advised we are inclined to think that some of the cases relied upon by the learned counsel for the appellants have perhaps gone farther than is warranted by the language of section 27,

arguments.qualifiers: as at present advised; inclined to think; perhaps

arguments.claim: Even under strict first-information-only rule for S.27, Swaran Singh's information led to initial specific discoveries

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal, however, it is sufficient to state that even if the argument put forward on behalf of the appellants. which apparently found favour with the High Court, is correct, the discoveries made at the instance of Swaran Singh cannot be ruled out of consideration.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not reassess evidence or points of fact rejected by trial court and High Court in criminal appeals due to limited scope of interference after sifting by lower courts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows principles laid down by this Court limiting reappreciation after lower courts' scrutiny.

holdings.text: As matter of prudence and caution, eye-witness testimony implicating particular accused requires circumstantial corroboration, which exists against each appellant satisfying the standard.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by this standard, which it was open to them to prescribe, it seems to us that the case of each of the appellants clearly fell within the rule which they had laid down for their own guidance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court's prudent standard distinguishing from accomplice corroboration; applies to facts finding assurance from circumstances against each.

holdings.text: Blood-stained pyjama recovered from Massa Singh provides reliable corroboration unaffected by criticisms on stain extent or improbability.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Criticisms considered below and insufficient to disturb conclusions within limited appellate scope.

holdings.text: Recovery of blood-stained weapons at instance of Lachhman Singh not to be discarded despite suspicions of police investigation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Point of fact rejected below; beyond Supreme Court's appellate function to reassess.

holdings.text: Discoveries at instance of Swaran Singh admissible under section 27 Evidence Act even under strict rule limiting to first information, as his was initial specific pointing out leading to distinct facts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes petitioner's strict interpretation; evidence shows Swaran's led to specific discoveries beyond general information.

holdings.text: Post-mortem finding of partially digested rice does not contradict prosecution's timing of occurrence before sunset.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Question of fact considered by High Court; digestion affected by many factors, no data on last meal.

holdings.text: Convictions of appellants under section 302 read with section 149 IPC for murder upheld; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants were tried by the Additional Sessions Judge at Amritsar and found guilty of having murdered two persons named Darshan Singh and Achhar Singh and sentenced to transportation for life. The High Court of Punjab upheld their conviction and sentence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial evidence corroborates eye-witnesses against each; rejects all challenges within limited scope.

holdings.text: Prior cases limiting section 27 Evidence Act admissibility to only first accused's information when multiple accused give statements may have gone too far and warrant review.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading allows independent statements from multiple accused leading to distinct discoveries; tentative view as at present advised.

justification_sets.label: Limited Scope of Supreme Court Interference in Criminal Appeals support
